Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Utilization of Natural Variation in Domesticated Strains of Saccharomyces Cerevisiae to Elucidate Metabolic Specialization

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: Saccharomyces cerevisiae has been domesticated by humans over thousands of years for use in brewing and baking. This domestication involves metabolic specialization of Saccharomyces cerevisiae. For example, brewing strains have been specialized to ferment substrates particular to a culture or region and to ferment under different conditions (temperature, fermentation length, oxygen availability, etc.). Genomic analysis has shown that these domesticated fermentation species have between 30,000-90,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with respect to the standard laboratory strain. Some of this natural genetic variation is responsible for the brewing strains adaptation to its particular fermentation process. This research will identify that causative genetic variation and illuminate how cells regulate their metabolism of fundamental nutrients such as carbon and nitrogen.

Broader impacts: From an educational standpoint, this project will have a vast broader impact. It will provide 20-40 undergraduates experience with genome-scale data in addition to standard molecular and microbiological techniques. These experiences will take place in the research-intensive course Bio 176: Research in Systems Biology. This course is an upper division project laboratory class focused directly on the specific aims of this project. This course is the capstone of the Biotechnology Program at Santa Clara University, through which students learn sophisticated microbiological, molecular biological, and biochemical techniques, and explore the social ramifications of biotechnology. This capstone is designed to integrate their technical skills with critical thinking skills allowing students to obtain skilled positions in life science research after graduation. In supporting these students and the development of this course, this research will strongly support the undergraduate-focused educational mission of Santa Clara University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microorganisms must maintain a highly complex metabolic network necessary for life in the face of an ever-changing environment.  Traditionally, the problem of homeostasis has been studied by focusing on a given nutrient or molecule (such as glucose or phosphate).  Though these studies have defined key players in uptake and utilization of various nutrients, they rarely could address how perturbations in one pathway affected the metabolic network as a whole.  But with the advent of genome-level technologies, we can now probe the state of the cell far more completely—allowing us to investigate how cells integrate information about both their extracellular environment and their intracellular metabolic network. 

 

This research proposal focused on how natural variation (changes in DNA that arise through both selective and non-selective evolutionary processes) adapts Saccharomyces cerevisiae to different ecological niches—both natural and man-made (such as different fermentation processes). Discovery of the connection between genetic changes (genotype) and observed phenomenon (phenotype) is crucial to understanding the process of evolution generally and how these connections relate to the inheritance of complex genetic diseases such as cancer and Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Saccharomyces cerevisiae has been domesticated by humans over thousands of years for use in brewing and baking.  This domestication involves metabolic specialization of Saccharomyces cerevisiae.  For example, brewing strains have been specialized to ferment substrates particular to a culture or region (i.e. grape mash for wine or rice for sake) and to ferment under different conditions (temperature, fermentation length, oxygen availability, etc).  Genomic analysis has shown that these domesticated fermentation species have between 30,000-90,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with respect to the standard laboratory strain.  Some of this natural genetic variation is responsible for the brewing strains adaptation to its particular fermentation process. Thus Saccharomyces cerevisiae was an ideal model organism for use in this proposal.

 

One of the promises of the genomic era is to elucidate the connection between natural genetic variation and phenotypic variation.  This proposal utilized Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a model system to further our understanding of this important area of research.  In addition to increasing our understanding of natural variation, this work provided discoveries into metabolic regulation.
